etymologies: late Middle English (in the sense ‘contributory, conducive’): from Old French, or from medieval Latin dispositivus, from Latin disposit- ‘arranged, disposed’, from the verb disponere (see dispose)

definitions: relating to or bringing about the settlement of an issue or the disposition of property

examples.text: such litigation will rarely be dispositive of any question

shortDefinitions: relating to or bringing about settlement of issue or disposition of property

definitions: dealing with the disposition of property by deed or will

examples.text: the testator had to make his signature after making the dispositive provisions

shortDefinitions: (in Scots and US law) dealing with disposition of property by deed or will

definitions: dealing with the settling of international conflicts by an agreed disposition of disputed territories

examples.text: a peace settlement in the nature of a dispositive treaty

shortDefinitions: dealing with settling of international conflicts by agreed disposition of disputed territories
